Slit-box/Framing-ML-Problems.title: Framing ML Problems
Slit-box/Framing-ML-Problems.content:
Framing ML Problems
Project: @gortiumâ€™s Journey To Become a Machine Learning Engineer
Repository: LinkedIn_Google_Cloud_Pro_ML_Eng_Cert_Framing_ML_Problems
Key terms

machine learning: Learning algorithms
supervised learning: Learning from data with labels
unsupervised learning: Learning from data without labels
Reinforcement Learning: Learning from try and error and a reward function
ML Solution Readiness: Assessment of the readiness of a ML solution

Data availability
Data quality
Data limitation
Responsable AI practices


ML Uses Cases: A task a ML can solve with a business context. Exemple:

Segmentation
Fraud detection
Demand forecasting


ML Problem Types:

Classification
Progression
clustering


Business Success Criteria: Specific measurable goal or outcomes that indicate whether a ML solution is successful in addressing the business problem. Exemple:

Improving accuracy
Reducing a cost
Increasing efficiency


Bias in ML:

Fair model predictions
Unbiased model predictions
Accurate model predictions


Business Impact Assessment: Impact of a specific ml solution and to communicate to stakeholders
Data readiness: Data is useful for ML training

Data availability
Data quality
Data limitation


Responsible AI Practices: Design in a way that it is ethical and trust worthy to avoid negative consequences and legal consequences

Translating business challenges into ML use cases
Github for teaching MLOps

Reproduccibility: Codespaces
Access to GPU: Machine Learning Codespaces
AI Coding Assistant: Copilot
Continuous Integration & Deploy: Github Actions

MLOps?

WHY?: You need to retrain and redeploy ML model continuously
HOW?: Github codespaces, copilot, actions
WHAT?: Github actions link to any platform

Transclude of Framing-ML-Problems-2024-03-17-22.23.16.excalidraw
MLOps rule of 25
No silver bullet.

25% DevOps
25% Data engineering
25% MLOps
25% Stakeholder communication

Github Codespaces

AI augmented coding
Github Copilot

Paid option

Twinny + Ollama
(Not in the course. My own research)

Free
Self-hosted
Private

Hugging Face
Three main part:

Models
Dataset
Spaces

Defining ML problems
Defining business success criteria
Identifying risk to feasibility of ML solutions

Slit-box/LinkedIn-Google-Cloud-Professio.title: LinkedIn Google Cloud Professional Machine Learning Engineer Certification Preparation
Slit-box/LinkedIn-Google-Cloud-Professio.content:
LinkedIn Google Cloud Professional Machine Learning Engineer Certification Preparation
The exam:
Google Cloud Professional Machine Learning Engineer Certification
Ressources:

LinkedIn - Prepare for the Google Cloud Professional Machine Learning Engineer Certification

Exam

~2 hours
50-60 Questions
Online or in person
Recommended 3+ years industry experience
1+ year experience with GCP

Six sections in the exam

Framing ML Problems
Architecting ML solutions
Designing data preparation and processing systems
Developing ML models
Automating and orchestrating ML pipelines
Monitoring, optimizing, and maintaining ML solutions

Slit-box/robot-framework.title: robot framework
Slit-box/robot-framework.content:
robot framework
testing, python, programming, open source
Robot framework is a open source test framework that offer a lots of automatically generated documentation and test report in HTML out of the box.
Useful links:

Import constants in robot framework
Robot-Framework Cheat-Sheet
BuiltIn keywords
Quick Start Guide
Beginners Guide

index.title: index
index.content:
Welcome to my public second brain! ğŸ§ 

Hi! Iâ€™m Thierry Pouplier, an electrical engineer with a deep specialization in machine learning, control theory, and robotics. My journey in technology has spanned from designing autonomous systems and working on embedded hardware to exploring the intricacies of software development, particularly in mobile robotics and AI-driven solutions.
Over the years, Iâ€™ve worked on diverse projects, including developing SLAM algorithms, optimizing robotic control systems, and integrating AI models into real-world applications. Alongside these professional experiences, Iâ€™ve maintained an extensive knowledge repository in Obsidian, where I document insights, technical breakthroughs, and reflections on my work.
Now, Iâ€™m excited to share this knowledge in my digital garden. Here, Iâ€™ll be documenting not just technical insights, but also learnings from courses and projects I pursue. My goal is to create a resource for myself and others who are equally passionate about advancing in fields like machine learning, robotics, and beyond.
Feel free to explore my digital garden, where you can follow my journey through evolving ideas and discoveries. Welcomeâ€”thereâ€™s much more to come!
Two Paths From Here:


My Portfolio


My Notes
